TemplateInfo.Name: UKMOD Statistics - Baseline/Reform
TemplateInfo.Title: UKMOD Statistics - Baseline vs Reforms
TemplateInfo.Subtitle: Results for [baseCountry]: [baseSys] vs [refSysList]
TemplateInfo.GeneralDescription:
Income concepts:

Market/Original incomes are the sum of income from employment and self-employment plus income from other sources. Other sources include income from investment, property, private pensions, private transfers, children younger than 16, minus private transfers paid to other households.

All analyses of disposable income are presented on two bases: Before Housing Costs (BHC) and After Housing Costs (AHC).

Disposable income BHC is the sum of market incomes and benefits (incl. pensions) minus taxes and national insurance contributions.

Disposable income AHC equals disposable income BHC minus housing costs, where housing costs are from the Households Below Average Income (HBAI) micro-data. Housing costs include: rent (gross of housing benefit); water rates; community water charges and council water charges; mortgage interest payments; structural insurance premiums.

Equivalised household (benefit unit) disposable income is the total disposable income of the household (benefit unit) divided by the OECD scale (which is often referred to as the modified OECD scale), rescaled to a couple without children following the HBAI approach. The benefit unit is the nuclear family - the couple (cohabiting or married) or single adult plus any dependent children. The equivalence scale attributes a weight of 0.67 to the head of the household/benefit unit, a weight of 0.33 to any other adult aged 16 or above and for any child aged 14-15, and a weight of 0.2 to every child aged 0-14.

Decile groups are calculated by ranking individuals according to their equivalised household (benefit unit) disposable income – either BHC or AHC – and dividing them into ten similar-sized groups.

All monetary amounts - except for the fiscal overview - are presented in average weekly amounts and in GBP (i.e. in the currency defined for the UKMOD output file).

The unit of analysis is the individual, so the populations and percentages in the tables are numbers and percentages of individuals.

Poverty indicators:

Households are defined as being at risk of poverty (poor) if their equivalised household disposable income is below the poverty line. The poverty line is defined as 60% of the country specific median equivalised household disposable income. The poverty gap is the difference between the poverty line and the median income of people at-risk-of poverty divided by the poverty line. The median income of people at-risk-of poverty is based on equivalised household disposable income.

NOTE: negative equivalised household disposable incomes are recoded to 0 for all poverty related results.

Inequality indicators:

Gini index measures the distribution of income within a country where 0 means perfect income equality and 1 means perfect income inequality.

The S80/20 ratio - also referred to as the income quintile share ratio - is the ratio of the total income received by the 20% of the population with the highest income to that received by the bottom 20%.

NOTE: negative incomes are recoded to 0 for results on Gini and S80/20 indicators.

Definition of age-groups:

Sub-population groups are defined as follows:

·    Children are defined as being under 16 or under 19 years old and in full-time non-advanced education and not married.

·    Elderly are persons aged 65 or older

·    Adults are defined as anyone who is not a child and not an elderly (i.e. being aged 16 or above, or 19 or above if full-time non-advanced education and not married, and up to the age of 64)

·    Someone is in work if he/she has income from employment or self-employment

 

The income concepts used throughout and the corresponding UKMOD variables are as follows:

Total market income: ils_origy (UKMOD variable)

Employment and self-employment income: ils_earns

Means-tested non-pension benefits: ils_benmt

Non-means-tested non-pension benefits: ils_bennt

Pensions: ils_pen

All benefits: ils_ben = ils_pen + ils_benmt + ils_bennt

Direct taxes: ils_tax

Employee National Insurance contributions: ils_sicee

Self-employed National Insurance contributions: ils_sicse

Other National Insurance contributions: ils_sicot

All employee/self-employed/other National Insurance Contributions: ils_sicdy = ils_sicee + ils_sicse + ils_sicot

Disposable income BHC: ils_dispy = ils_origy + ils_ben – ils_tax – ils_sicdy

Disposable income AHC: il_dispy_ahc = ils_dispy – xhc_hbai

Employer National Insurance contributions: ils_sicer

Credited National Insurance contributions: ils_sicct

 

Total market incomes in more detail:

Employment and self-employment income: ils_earns = yem + yse + yemmc_s (in 2020)

Other sources: yiy + yot01 + ypr + ypp + yptot + yptmp – xmp

Employment income: yem

Self-employment income: yse

Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme contribution paid by employer (in 2020 only with simulation of Covid-19 shocks): yemmc_s

Investment income: yiy

Income from odd jobs: yot01

Property income: ypr

Personal pension: ypp

Private transfers (non-taxable): yptot

Received maintenance payment: yptmp

Maintenance paid: xmp

Government revenue through taxes and National Insurance contributions in more detail:

Direct taxes: ils_tax = tin_s + tmu

Simulated taxes: ils_taxsim = tin_s

Personal Income Tax: tin_s

Devolved taxes in Scotland: tin11_s

Devolved taxes in Wales: tin12_s

Non-devolved taxes: tin00_s

Council tax: tmu

Simulated Employee National Insurance contributions: ils_sicee = tscee_s

Simulated Self-employed National Insurance contributions: ils_sicse = tscse_s

Other National Insurance contributions (non-existent in the UK): ils_sicot

Simulated Employer National Insurance contributions (not part of disposable income): ils_sicer = tscer_s

 

Credited National Insurance contributions (not part of disposable income) (in 2020 only with simulation of Covid-19 shocks): ils_sicct = tscct_s

 

Government expenditure on benefits and tax credits in more detail:

Means-tested non-pension benefits: ils_benmt = bsauc_s - brduc_s + bsa_s + bunmt_s + bsadi_s + boamt_s + bmu_s + bho_s - brd_s + bwkmt_s + bfamt_s + bmamt_s + bmamt01_s + bmascmt_s + bchmt_s + bchmt01_s + bmascmt01_s + bched01_s + bched02_s + bhosc01_s + bsaec_s

Non-means-tested non-pension benefits: ils_bennt = bedes + bedsl + bdioa + bdisc + bdimb + bdiscwa + bdimbwa + bdict01 + bdict02 + bdiwi + bcrdi + bcrdicm_s + bdisv + bhlwk + buntr + bot + bmaer + bmana + boaht_s + bch_s + bunct_s + bchht_s + bwkmcee_s (in 2020) + bwkmcse_s (in 2020)

Pensions: ils_pen = boact00 + boactcm + boawr + bsuwd

Simulated benefits: ils_bensim = bwkmt_s + bfamt_s + bsa_s + bsadi_s + boamt_s + bho_s + bmu_s + bunmt_s + bmamt_s + bmamt01_s + bmascmt_s + bsauc_s + boaht_s + bch_s + bunct_s + bchmt_s + bcrdicm_s + bchht_s + bwkmcee_s (in 2020) + bwkmcse_s (in 2020) - brd_s - brduc_s

 

Universal Credit: bsauc_s

Benefit cap (reducing Universal Credit): brduc_s

Income Support & income-based Jobseekers Allowance (unless simulated separately): bsa_s

Income-based Jobseeker's Allowance: bunmt_s

Income-related Employment and Support Allowance: bsadi_s

Pension Credit: boamt_s

Council Tax Benefit/Reduction: bmu_s

Housing Benefit: bho_s

Benefit cap (reducing Housing Benefit): brd_s

Working Tax Credit: bwkmt_s

Child Tax Credit: bfamt_s

Sure Start Maternity Grant: bmamt_s

Healthy Start (food) voucher: bmamt01_s

Best Start Grant (Scotland): bmascmt_s

Scottish Child Payment: bchmt_s

Scottish Child Payment Bridging Payment: bchmt01_s

Best Start foods (Scotland): bmascmt01_s

Free School meals (Scotland): bched01_s

School clothing grant (Scotland): bched02_s

Discretionary Housing Payments (Scotland): bhosc01_s

Cost of Living Payment: bsaec_s

Winter Fuel Allowance: boaht_s

Child Benefit: bch_s

Contribution-based Jobseeker's Allowance: bunct_s

Scottish Carer’s Allowance Supplement: bcrdicm_s

Scottish Child Winter Heating Assistance: bchht_s

Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme (in 2020 only with simulation of Covid-19 shocks): bwkmcee_s

Self-Employment Income Support Scheme (in 2020 only with simulation of Covid-19 shocks): bwkmcse_s

Student payments: bedes

Student Loan: bedsl

Attendance allowance: bdioa

Disability Living Allowance: bdisc

Disability Living (mobility) Allowance: bdimb

Personal Independence Payment living allowance: bdiscwa

Personal Independence Payment mobility: bdimbwa

Incapacity Benefit: bdict01

Contributory Employment and Support Allowance: bdict02

Industrial injuries pension: bdiwi

Invalid Carer's Allowance: bcrdi

Severe Disablement Allowance: bdisv

Statutory Sick Pay: bhlwk

Training Allowance: buntr

Statutory Maternity Pay: bmaer

Maternity Allowance: bmana

other non-means-tested benefits: bot

Base State pension: boact00

Second State Pension: boactcm

War pension: boawr

Widow's pension: bsuwd

Filter.Name: FilterAdults
Filter.FormulaString: !(DATA_VAR[@age]<16 | ((DATA_VAR[@age]<19 & DATA_VAR[@dec]>0 & DATA_VAR[@dec] < 6) & DATA_VAR[@dms]!=2)) && !((DATA_VAR[@age] >= DATA_VAR[@PensionAgeMale] && DATA_VAR[@dgn] == 1) || (DATA_VAR[@age] >= DATA_VAR[@PensionAgeFemale] && DATA_VAR[@dgn] == 0))

Filter.Name: FilterAdultsActive
Filter.FormulaString: !(DATA_VAR[@age]<16 | ((DATA_VAR[@age]<19 & DATA_VAR[@dec]>0 & DATA_VAR[@dec] < 6) & DATA_VAR[@dms]!=2)) && !((DATA_VAR[@age] >= DATA_VAR[@PensionAgeMale] && DATA_VAR[@dgn] == 1) || (DATA_VAR[@age] >= DATA_VAR[@PensionAgeFemale] && DATA_VAR[@dgn] == 0)) && DATA_VAR[@ilsEarns] > 0

Page.Name: FiscalOverview
Page.Title: Market incomes and fiscal overview
Page.Subtitle: Yearly, mill., currency as defined in EM output
Page.Description: The table shows total annual amounts and number of income recipients/tax payers of the specified tax-benefit system(s). It provides an overview of market incomes as well as the fiscal policies covered in EUROMOD.

Row.Name: Government revenue through taxes and National Insurance contributions
... employer National Insurance contributions (not part of disposable income)
Credited National Insurance contributions (not part of disposable income)
Government expenditure on benefits and tax credits
Income Support & income-based Jobseekers Allowance (unless simulated separately)

Page.Name: Poverty
Page.Title: Basic Poverty Indices using a fixed poverty line
Page.Description:
The table shows the poverty headcount of the total population and different sub-population groups as well as the poverty gap and the poverty line.

The poverty line (but not the poverty status) is based on the base scenario for the baseline and reform results.

Table.Title: Poverty indicators (based on incomes BHC)

ReformColumn.Name: refSys
ReformColumn.Title: [refSys]
ReformColumn.Tooltip: Equivalised disposable household income lower than 60% of the country specific median income.

Row.Name: Poverty Gap
Row.Tooltip: Difference between the median equivalised disposable income of people at-risk-of-poverty and poverty line, as a percentage of poverty line.

Row.Name: Fixed Poverty Line
Row.Tooltip: 60% of the country specific median equivalised disposable household income.

Table.Title: Poverty indicators (based on incomes AHC)

ReformColumn.Name: refSys
ReformColumn.Title: [refSys]
ReformColumn.Tooltip: Equivalised disposable household income lower than 60% of the country specific median income.

Row.Name: Poverty Gap AHC
Row.Title: Poverty Gap
Row.Tooltip: Difference between the median equivalised disposable income of people at-risk-of-poverty and poverty line, as a percentage of poverty line.

Row.Name: Fixed Poverty Line AHC
Row.Title: Fixed Poverty Line
Row.Tooltip: 60% of the country specific median equivalised disposable household income.

Table.Title: Poverty headcount by decile (based on incomes BHC)

Column.Name: Poverty Rates for baseSys
Column.Title: Poverty Rates for [baseSys] (base)
Column.Tooltip: Equivalised disposable household income lower than 60% of the country specific median income.

Column.Name: Poverty Count for baseSys
Column.Title: Poverty Count for [baseSys] (base)
Column.Tooltip: Equivalised disposable household income lower than 60% of the country specific median income.

ReformColumn.Name: Poverty Count for refSys
ReformColumn.Title: Poverty Count for [refSys]
ReformColumn.Tooltip: Equivalised disposable household income lower than 60% of the country specific median income.

CellAction.FormulaString: (REF_COL[Poverty Rates for refSys] - BASE_COL[Poverty Rates for baseSys]) * 100
REF_COL[Poverty Count for refSys] - BASE_COL[Poverty Count for baseSys]

Page.Name: PovertyFloating
Page.Title: Basic Poverty Indices using a floating poverty line
Page.Description:
The tabkkle shows the poverty headcount of the total population and different sub-population groups as well as the poverty gap and the poverty line.

The poverty line is based on the income distribution in the respective scenario (i.e. baseline or reform).

Page.Name: Inequality
Page.Title: Basic Inequality Indices
Page.Description:
The table shows the Gini index and S80/20 indicator for selected income concepts:

·   The comparison of the original income with the original income after taxes shows to what extent taxes contribute to redistribution.

·   The comparison of the original income plus public pensions after taxes with the original income after taxes shows the role of public pensions for redistribution.

·   The comparison of the original income with the disposable income shows the extent of income redistribution performed by the tax-benefit systems as a whole (incl. National Insurance contributions and benefits beyond public pensions).

The calculated indexes are income concept and system-specific and are all equivalised at the household level. The definition of the top and bottom 20% is always based on equivalised household disposable income.

Table.Title: (based on incomes BHC)

Column.Name: Gini baseSys
Column.Title: Gini [baseSys]
Column.Tooltip: Measures the distribution of income within a country where 0 means perfect income equality and 1 means perfect income inequality.

Column.Name: S80/S20 baseSys
Column.Title: S80/S20 [baseSys]
Column.Tooltip: Ratio of total income received top quintile to that received by bottom quintile.

ReformColumn.Name: Gini refSys
ReformColumn.Title: Gini [refSys]
ReformColumn.Tooltip: Measures the distribution of income within a country where 0 means perfect income equality and 1 means perfect income inequality.

ReformColumn.Name: S80/S20 refSys
ReformColumn.Title: S80/S20 [refSys]
ReformColumn.Tooltip: Ratio of total income received top quintile to that received by bottom quintile.

Row.Name: Original Income
Row.Tooltip: Earnings from employment and self-employment plus other market incomes (from investment, property, private pensions, private transfers, children younger than 16) minus private transfers paid to other households.

Row.Name: Original Income after Taxes/SIC
Row.Tooltip: Original income – Taxes – National Insurance Contributions.

Row.Name: Original Income incl. Public Pensions after Taxes/SIC
Row.Tooltip: Original income + Public Pensions – Taxes – National Insurance Contributions.

Row.Name: Disposable Income
Row.Tooltip: Original income + Benefits (incl. Public Pensions) – Taxes – National Insurance Contributions.

Table.Title: (based on incomes AHC)

Column.Name: Gini baseSys
Column.Title: Gini [baseSys]
Column.Tooltip: Measures the distribution of income within a country where 0 means perfect income equality and 1 means perfect income inequality.

Column.Name: S80/S20 baseSys
Column.Title: S80/S20 [baseSys]
Column.Tooltip: Ratio of total income received top quintile to that received by bottom quintile.

ReformColumn.Name: Gini refSys
ReformColumn.Title: Gini [refSys]
ReformColumn.Tooltip: Measures the distribution of income within a country where 0 means perfect income equality and 1 means perfect income inequality.

ReformColumn.Name: S80/S20 refSys
ReformColumn.Title: S80/S20 [refSys]
ReformColumn.Tooltip: Ratio of total income received top quintile to that received by bottom quintile.

Row.Name: Original Income
Row.Tooltip: Earnings from employment and self-employment plus other market incomes (from investment, property, private pensions, private transfers, children younger than 16) minus private transfers paid to other households.

Row.Name: Original Income after Taxes/SIC
Row.Tooltip: Original income – Taxes – National Insurance Contributions.

Row.Name: Original Income incl. Public Pensions after Taxes/SIC
Row.Tooltip: Original income + Public Pensions – Taxes – National Insurance Contributions.

Row.Name: Disposable Income
Row.Tooltip: Original income + Benefits (incl. Public Pensions) – Taxes – National Insurance Contributions - Housing Costs.

Page.Name: MeanEqIncomeHH
Page.Title: Mean equivalised household income breakdowns
Page.Description:
The table shows the mean equivalised household income (disposable & original) of the total population and different sub-population groups. The last two rows of each table show the mean income of the total population (All) and the population at-risk-of-poverty (Poor).

The calculation of the decile groups are based on equivalised household disposable income. The decile groups and the poverty status are based on the base scenario. The reform results show how income changes within each group (people are not moving from one group to the other).

Table.Title: By decile groups (based on incomes BHC)

Row.Name: Poor
Row.Tooltip: Equivalised disposable household income lower than 60% of the country specific median income.

Page.Name: SharesIncome
Page.Title: Shares of Income breakdowns
Page.Description: The table shows the shares of unequivalised household income (disposable and original) received by different sub-population groups. The deciles are based on the equivalised household disposable income. It answers the question of how much income is concentrated in each sub-population group. The last row shows how much income is concentrated at the population at-risk-of-poverty.

Table.Title: By decile groups (based on incomes BHC)

Page.Name: GainersLosers
Page.Title: Share (in %) of gainers and losers (counting individuals)
Page.Subtitle: based on changes in equivalised household disposable income
Page.Description: The table shows the share of individuals (as % of the population) who are gainers/losers based on changes in their equivalised household disposable income, by household type. Not all household types are mutually exclusive. The elderly are defined as being aged 65 and over. Children are defined as being under 16 or under 19 years old and in full-time non-advanced education and not married. An earner is defined as having positive employment or self-employment income. A lone parent is defined as a parent of resident dependent children, not cohabiting with a partner (whether or not any other resident is the parent of the child is irrelevant). A young mother is defined as being under 25 years old and with a dependent child.
